Subject to certain exceptions, Turkish legislation prohibits Turkish-resident individuals from obtaining foreign currency loans both from foreign lenders and domestic lenders licensed in Turkey. Therefore, students who have a legal residency in Turkey cannot obtain foreign currency or foreign currency indexed loans from Prodigy Finance unless they move their residency abroad.
There is a discussion as to whether or not Turkish residents are able to obtain foreign currency loans from foreign lenders outside of Turkey on a reverse enquiry basis where there is no marketing or solicitation activity performed in Turkey or directed towards Turkish residents and no credit activity takes place in Turkey. However, the regulators have been taking relatively inconsistent positions as to the scope of this restriction, and, therefore, we recommend that PF receives feedback from the regulators (i.e., Turkish Central Bank, Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency (BRSA)) in writing before it undertakes any such activity involving Turkish residents.

A banking or a financing licence would be required to extend credit in Turkey though as mentioned in 1a above, Turkish residents are not permitted to obtain foreign exchange loan even from locally licensed banks or financing institutions.

Despite being inconsistent, Turkish regulators take a very conservative approach towards foreign exchange lending from abroad. Hence, if accepted by the regulators, any activity should take place outside of Turkey to the extent possible in order to support the presumption that the loan is provided on a reverse enquiry basis.

Provided that (i) the regulator's consent is sought before entering into a relationship with the customer; (ii) the contractual relationship is established thereafter on a reverse enquiry basis outside of Turkey; and, (iii) the activities performed within the context of "servicing" does not involve any additional banking activity such as offering new banking/securities products and services, no additional license would be required.

Since the activity will take place outside of Turkey and the contractual relation between the Turkish resident and the relevant PF entity will be governed by the laws of the relevant jurisdiction (e.g., the loan agreement) it should not be subject to any other restrictions other than (i) public policy considerations which are determined by the Turkish courts on a case by case basis; and, (ii) other restrictions summarized above.
Note that we are not aware of any court precedent to that effect but the Law No. 6502 on the Protection of Consumers may be a potential area of concern for public policy matters.

Assuming that PF does not violate any solicitation rule or licensing requirement in Turkey, should there be any public policy consideration as discussed above, it may prevent the enforcement of a judicial decision in Turkey vis-a-vis the Turkish resident.

Marketing of lending activities in Italy is not permitted unless the relevant entity has obtained an authorisation to grant loans in Italy. Marketing is deemed to take place in Italy (and, as a result, the Italian licensing requirements are triggered) when the marketing activities target recipients located (i.e. resident or established) in Italy, irrespective of whether: (i) the relevant marketing activity takes place in Italy; and (ii) the recipients are consumers / retail clients. With specific reference to marketing via distance communication means (e.g. internet) the Bank of Italy Regulation (see 5a below) clarifies that banking services - including lending activities - are deemed to be performed in Italy when, inter alia, one or more of the following conditions are met: (i) the marketing activities are addressed to persons located in Italy; (ii) the website of the financial institution is in the Italian language or otherwise refers to Italian clients or specificities; (iii) the website can be accessed through websites which specifically target Italian clients; (iv) marketing material is published / spread in Italy; or (v) information on products are sent to clients in Italy through emails or other distance means. In this respect, we note that the website and marketing material of Prodigy Finance would not specifically target persons in Italy and assume that the conditions above would not be met. Nonetheless, pursuant to said Bank of Italy Regulation, banking services are also deemed to be performed in Italy where the relevant lender accepts orders coming from persons located in Italy or, in any case, where it effectively performs services toward said persons (see 2a below). On the other hand, the Bank of Italy Regulation provides that marketing / lending activities are not deemed to be performed in Italy if: (i) the relevant website specifies that the offer is not directed to Italian clients; (ii) the relevant institution sets up appropriate procedures to decline any orders received from persons in Italy; (iii) the relevant institution actually declines any orders coming from persons in Italy. In light of the foregoing, in the case at stake, although the marketing activities performed by Prodigy Finance would not specifically target students resident in Italy, the Italian licensing requirements should apply to the extent that said marketing activities are followed by orders / offers to conclude a loan agreement coming from Italian students and Prodigy Finance does not decline said orders / offers. As to licensing requirements, in order to obtain the authorisation to grant loans in Italy, in the absence of EU passporting rights, an EU financial institution should file an application with the Bank of Italy and meet certain requirements, including inter alia the setting up of a permanent establishment in Italy, which should be capitalised depending on the type of activities (from Euro 2,000,000 to 3,000,000). Please refer to 2a below with regard to reliance on duly licensed intermediaries.

For the breach of the transparency requirements envisaged by the Italian Banking Act and the Bank of Italy Regulation, a regulatory fine could be imposed ranging between Euro 2,580 and 258,225 (depending on the type of breach). For the breach of the transparency requirements imposed under the Consumer Code (i.e. relating to consumers' protection) the regulatory fine would be between Euro 5,000 and 50,000. In case of serious breaches, such amounts could be doubled. In addition to the foregoing, the breach of certain requirements (e.g. contract formation formalities; lack of pre-contract information; breach of provisions relating to right of withdrawal) could render the relevant agreement null and void (thus unenforceable). The Italian regulators may order the suspension of a banking service / product in breach of relevant Italian rules acting in the exercise of their supervisory functions. Suspension/ revocation of license should be imposed only for most serious breaches. The breach of Italian transparency requirements should not per se constitute a criminal offence (i.e. except where the relevant person acts with fraud). However, please note that the performance of lending activities in Italy in breach of the licensing requirements mentioned under answer 1a and 2a above would constitute a criminal offence (punished with imprisonment from 6 months to 4 years and a fine from Euro 2,065 to 10,329).

In order to avoid breach of the usury rates, interest envisaged under loan agreements should be lower than the usury rates determined as above. Italian loan agreements usually include a clause pursuant to which if the interest rate envisaged by the contract results at any time to be equal to or higher than current usury rate, the effective interest rate applied between the parties shall be deemed as automatically reduced below the current usury rate.

Law No. 2011/012 of 6 May 2011, relating to Consumer Protection in Cameroon, relates to all transactions relating to the supply, distribution, sale and exchange of technology, goods and services relating to consumer protection (“Consumer Protection Law”). - Pursuant to section 4 of the Consumer Protection Law, Unfair business practices are regulated, and prohibited in all contracts. “Unfair business practices” are defined as practices that adopts a method, including an oral or written declaration or a visual representation that compromises fairness in a transaction. - Contractual clauses which impose a unilateral arbitration clause are expressly prohibited and shall be deemed void. - Section 6 of the aforementioned law provides that standard agreements or adhesion contracts must be drafted in English and French in characters that are visible and legible at first glance. The agreements must not make reference to other contracts, rules or practices and documents unknown to the public or not put at the disposal before or during the execution of such contract. - The consumer shall have a right to withdraw, within a period not exceeding fourteen (14) days, with effect from the date of execution of the contract. With respect to the granting of loans, consumers must be informed in writing of the cash price, interest amount, annual interest rate, interest rate on arrears, number of instalments, frequency and periodicity of such instalments and total amount payable (see section 9 of the Consumer Protection Law).

Execution of loan agreements in Ontario, other than for an isolated transaction, would likely mean that Prodigy Finance would be considered to be carrying on business in Ontario, and therefore required to obtain an extra-provincial business licence under the Extra-Provincial Corporations Act (Ontario) ("EPCA"). Frequency, magnitude, and duration of transactions in the province, and location where contracts are entered into are influential factors in the carry-on-business analysis. Obtaining a licence is a relatively easy process. It requires appointment of an agent for service in Ontario. Where a foreign corporation is required to be licensed, but is not, the principal impact of the EPCA is that such a corporation cannot bring or maintain proceedings in Ontario courts.

There are no licensing requirements in Ontario that must be satisfied in order for the lender itself to perform post-contractual servicing/enforcement activities. However, collection agencies and other agents who assist creditors to collect debts are subject to licensing requirements. If Prodigy Finance is the lender and is servicing the debt, it is not required to be licensed as a collection agency.

When calculating the interest rate, "interest" is broadly defined to include all charges, fees, expenses etc. payable in connection with the advance of credit. The primary consequence of non-compliance is the possibility that a borrower may argue in defence of an enforcement proceeding that the criminal interest prohibition applies so as to render the contract illegal. It is also likely that the CPA credit advertising restrictions would apply. If the promotional materials include an offer of credit, plus the statement of an interest rate or the amount of any payment, they must also disclose the annual percentage rate (APR), length of term, price of servicing and cost of borrowing. An advertisement stating or implying that no interest is payable for a period of time under a credit agreement has additional disclosure requirements. Marketing materials must not contain false or misleading representations; Prodigy Finance and its partners/collaborators must not engage in any deceptive marketing practices.

No licensing/authorization for extension of credit would be required, but if the loan agreement is executed in Ontario by the foreign student (who would be a consumer under the CPA) and the funds are advanced into Ontario then in our view, it is likely the CPA would apply, including cost of credit disclosure, prohibitions on unfair trade practices and misleading representations, as well as form, content and ongoing disclosure requirements in connection with the loan agreement.

Licensing: There are no licensing requirements in Ontario that must be satisfied in order for the lender itself to perform post-contractual servicing/enforcement activities. Collection agencies and other agents who assist creditors to collect debts are subject to licensing requirements, but the lender itself is not. As noted above, if not extra-provincially registered where carrying on business in Ontario, a lender may not commence proceedings in Ontario courts. Bringing enforcement proceedings would not, in itself, constitute carrying on business in Ontario.
Other Considerations: Lenders are confined by the CPA to impose the following charges on a borrower in default: reasonable charges for legal costs the lender incurs in collecting a required payment; reasonable charges for costs the lender incurs in realizing or protecting a security interest after default; and reasonable charges for costs the lender incurs as a result of an instrument of payment being dishonoured. Active marketing or soliciting business in Alberta would constitute carrying on business in Alberta, triggering the requirement to obtain an extra-provincial business licence under the ABCA. Where a foreign corporation is required to be licensed, but is not, the principal impact of the extra-provincial business licensing provisions of the ABCA is that such a corporation cannot bring or maintain proceedings in Alberta courts.
It is also likely that the FTA credit advertising restrictions would apply. If the promotional materials include an offer of credit, plus the statement of an interest rate or the amount of any payment, they must also disclose the annual percentage rate (APR), length of term, non-interest finance charges, and total cost of credit. An advertisement stating or implying that no interest is payable for a period of time under a credit agreement has additional disclosure requirements. Marketing materials must not contain false or misleading representations; Prodigy Finance and its partners/collaborators must not engage in any deceptive marketing practices.

No licensing/authorization for extension of credit would be required, but if the loan agreement is executed in Alberta by the foreign student (who would be a consumer under the FTA) and the funds are advanced into Alberta then in our view, it is likely the FTA would apply, including cost of credit disclosure, prohibitions on unfair trade practices and misleading representations, as well as form, content and ongoing disclosure requirements in connection with the loan agreement.

Licensing: There are no licensing requirements in Alberta that must be satisfied in order for the lender itself to perform post-contractual servicing/enforcement activities. Collection agencies and other agents who assist creditors to collect debts are subject to licensing requirements, but the lender is not. As noted above, if not extra-provincially registered where carrying on business in Alberta, a lender may not commence proceedings in Alberta courts. Bringing enforcement proceedings would not, in itself, constitute carrying on business in Alberta.
Other Considerations: Lenders are confined by the FTA to impose the following charges on a borrower in default: reasonable charges for legal costs the lender incurs in collecting a required payment; reasonable charges for costs the lender incurs in realizing or protecting a security interest after default; and reasonable charges for costs the lender incurs as a result of an instrument of payment being dishonoured (FTA, s. 69). Assignments of wages made in favour of lenders are void in Alberta (FTA, s. 53).

The prohibitions are not limited to third party debt collection. Thus, Prodigy Finance and its affiliates would be exempt from the licensing requirement, but would still be prohibited from engaging in any of the prohibited practices while servicing a debt.

Under the CCQ and the QCPA, the lender must ensure that the obligation of the borrower under the loan is not (I) excessive, disproportionate or abusive (CCQ); or (ii) excessive, harsh or unconscionable (QCPA) in light of the borrower's circumstances and the terms of the loan. The primary consequence of non-compliance is the possibility that a borrower may ask the court to annul his/her obligation (the lender would still be able to recover its capital) or that his/her obligations be reduced and/or the terms of the loan modified. Under the Criminal Code (Canada), s. 347, the effective annual interest rate should not exceed 60%. When calculating the interest rate, "interest" is broadly defined to include all charges, fees, expenses etc. payable in connection with the advance of credit. The primary consequence of non-compliance is the possibility that a borrower may argue in defence of an enforcement proceeding that the criminal interest prohibition applies so as to render the contract illegal. By way of remedy, courts may disallow interest to the extent it exceeds the legal rate.

As noted above, if all of PF's marketing takes place on the internet, there could be an argument that the QCPA (and QLPA) did not apply to PF's activities although, even then, as stated above, our view is that PF would still likely be required to comply with the QCPA and perhaps the QLPA. However, if PF engages in active marketing in Quebec then our view is that it would be difficult to argue that the QCPA and the QLPA did not apply to PF's activities. Therefore, the QCPA permit and other requirements would likely apply to PF's Marketing and Extension of credit activities. QCPA loan requirements include: (i) mandatory form (such as font, paper) (not applicable to loans executed electronically); (ii) mandatory disclosure including obligatory clauses; (iii) prescribed manner of disclosing and calculating credit charges and credit rate; (iv) prescribed manner of sending and content of statements of account; and (v) requirements for amendments to loan contracts. In addition, QCPA restrictions on the advertising of credit and French language requirements would apply. The QCPA prohibits certain business practices including: (i) false or misleading representations (s.219); (ii) obligation to mention all important facts to consumers (s. 228); and (iii) obligation to mention identity of the business in all advertisements (s. 242). Regarding credit advertising, the QPCA provides that: (i) advertiser cannot induce the consumer to procure goods or services with the advertised credit or illustrate such goods or services in the advertisement (s. 245); (ii) if credit rate advertised, it must be calculated according to the rules in the QCPA and QCPR (including all credit charges) (s. 246); (iii) if the business wants to advertise any item in the following list, it must advertise all items: (a) credit charges, (b) number and duration of payment periods, (c) amount of each deferred payments, (d) total obligation of consumer, and (e) reference table of all credit charges applicable (QCPA, s. 247 ; QCPR, s. 84). French language requirements: Commercial advertising in Quebec must comply with the language requirements of the French Charter and the Regulation respecting the language of commerce and business (“Commerce Regulation”). Catalogues and brochures distributed in Quebec can be in a language other than French, as long as there is a French version of comparable quality and equally accessible, e.g. of equal quantity (s. 10). However, if the catalogue or brochure is intended for a limited public, such as participants at a fair or convention, the advertising materials can be in a language other than French (s. 12). Other exemptions may apply and certain items in the catalogue or brochure, such as English-only trademarks, are permitted to be in English only. Other rules for publicity in magazines, newspapers, etc. can be summarized upon request. A website is considered to be commercial publicity and there must be a French version of the website if the business has an address or establishment in Quebec. Active marketing in Quebec would constitute carrying on an activity or enterprise in Quebec and trigger the requirement to register a declaration under the QLPA. If a business fails to comply with the registration and filing requirements under the QLPA (when required to do so) it may, among other things, be fined or a legal proceeding that it has taken may be suspended until registration is effected.

If the loan is executed in Quebec by the foreign student (who would be a consumer under the QCPA) and the funds are advanced into Quebec then in our view, the QCPA would apply to PF's activities and to the loan and PF would be required to comply with the QCPA money lender's permit requirements (see response to 2a above) as well the other applicable QCPA requirements in respect of the form and content for the loan contract (see our response to 8a above) and perhaps the QCPA provisions in respect of the advertising of credit (although this is not clear if all of the marketing activities are being carried electronically). Further, as noted in our response to Question 8a, PF would likely be required to register a declaration under the QLPA as it would be more difficult to argue that PF was not carrying on an activity or enterprise in Quebec.

There are no licensing requirements in Quebec that must be satisfied in order for the lender itself to perform post-contractual servicing/enforcement activities of its own debt. However, any business collecting a debt is subject to certain obligations including not engaging in any of the following prohibited activities: (i) requiring debtor to pay fees that the creditor incurred to recover the debt; (ii) communicating with debtor once debtor has informed creditor in writing to communicate solely with his lawyer; (iii) communicating verbally with debtor if debtor has notified creditor that the debt is contested and that creditor may proceed with a legal action; (iv) harassing or unduly pressuring debtor; and (v) communicating with the family, friends or employer of debtor to collect the debt, unless that person is also a surety or the creditor only wants to obtain the address or telephone number of the debtor. Collection agencies and other agents who assist creditors to collect debts are subject to permit requirements under the Collection Agencies Act. Engaging in enforcement activities in Quebec may make it more difficult for PF to argue that it is not carrying on an activity or enterprise in Quebec and does not have to file a declaration under the QLPA. A lender which does not comply with the filing and registration requirements of the QLPA (when required to do so) may be fined and any proceedings it has taken in Quebec courts may be suspended until registration is effected. In our view, it is unlikely that bringing enforcement proceedings would, in and of itself, constitute carrying on an activity or enterprise in Quebec and require that PF be registered under the QLPA unless PF engaged in other enforcement activities in Quebec.
Other Considerations: The QCPA regulates a lender's recourses when a borrower is in default: (i) in order to accelerate a loan, the loan contract must include a clause of forfeiture of the benefit of the term (in prescribed language ) and the lender must give the borrower 30 days notice (in the prescribed form) and a statement of account, and the borrower may: (a) either remedy the default; or (b) present a motion to the court to have the terms and conditions of payment prescribed in the loan contract changed; (ii) no costs may be claimed from a borrower unless the amount is precisely indicated in the loan contract; (iii) the credit charges disclosed in the loan contract must include all charges, whether imposed as a penalty, arrears, extension charge or otherwise and these charges must be disclosed and computed in the manner provided in the QCPA and the QCPR; and (iii) Quebec courts may disallow a lender's claim for legal costs incurred in collecting a debt. An assignment of wages to secure payment of a debt is valid in Quebec, as long as certain conditions are respected such as notification/consent of debtor. Creditor may not be permitted to seize more than the portion of the wages which is not exempt from seizure under the Quebec Code of Civil Procedure.

Limited statutory restrictions in Mexico exist regarding the amounts that could be charged as interests in a commercial credit (interest cannot be charged in advance and can only be collected or considered as due once they have been accrued, and the payment of interest-on-interest cannot be legally agreed upon by the parties in advance). Additionally, the Mexican Central Bank has authority to regulate interest rates and fees charged by certain Mexican financial entities. Recently, the Mexican Supreme Court passed a mandatory ruling (jurisprudencia) allowing judges to reduce interest rates when they believe the interest rate agreed upon by the parties imply usury based on certain criteria that includes the relationship among the parties, the characteristics of the lender and the borrower, use of proceeds, amount and term of the loans, whether it is secured or unsecured, interest charged by Mexican banking institutions for comparison purposes only, inflation, market conditions, among other things. In addition, federal legislation considers as a criminal conduct obtaining any usury advantage from a person in precarious economic conditions or with low education (ignorance) through any contract or agreement pursuant to which interests or gains above the average market conditions are stipulated.

Since the activities described above involve offering credit on a regular or professional basis within Mexico and may be deemed to be made within Mexican territory, then anti-money laundering regulation would apply. Please find below a brief summary of some of the obligations set forth in the anti-money laundering regulation for persons offering credit in Mexico on a regular or professional basis: (i) file notices to the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit (Secretaría de Hacienda y Crédito Público) for those transactions exceeding certain thresholds included in the anti-money laundering regulation. (ii) identify clients and users of its services. (iii) request certain information from the client regarding its status in the Mexican Internal Revenue Service (Servicio de Administración Tributaria). (iv) obtain certain representations from its client with respect to beneficial ownership and, as the case may be, certain information on that regard. (v) protect and keep the information of its clients. (vi) appoint a representative before the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit for the purposes established in the anti-money laundering regulation.

The acceptance of an offer by students within Mexican territory (or e-signing of the corresponding loan agreements) could be construed as an actual execution of the agreement subject to such offer; thus, should this kind of execution is made on a regular basis, PF could subject to consumer protection regulation regarding publicity matters ("Transparency Regulation"). To the extent the extension of credit activities are deemed to constitute granting of credit to the public on a regular basis within Mexican territory, the Transparency Regulation would apply. Please find below a brief summary of some of the publicity rules set forth in the Transparency Regulation: (i) Advertising must be true and accurately describe the product or service offered, avoiding any misleading information. (ii) No unfair competition elements must be included (i.e., misleading information about the benefit of the relevant product at the expense of the competitors). (iii) The requirements to access the credit offered are clearly stated on a non- discriminatory basis. (iv) Sites or places in which additional information can be found must be indicated. (v) All fees and the methodology to calculate them must be disclosed. (vi) Interest rates (express as the aggregate annual cost) must be disclosed pursuant to some regulation published by the Mexican Central Bank. (vii) Advertising must be coherent and updated on a regular basis. (viii) Promotions must clearly state their expiration date.

Non-judiciary collection activities are subject to certain rules and standards if performed by entities granting credit with the characteristics of the PF services to the public on a regular basis within Mexican territory. In this context the following obligations, among other, would apply to PF: (i) Implementation of a mechanism for the identification of the debtor must be set up before establishing the first contact with him. (ii) Indicate, during the first contact with the debtor, whether verbally or in written, the following information (a) corporate name of the person and individuals performing the collection activities, (b) domicile, telephone number and name of the persons in charge of the collection activities, (c) name of the entity that granted the loan, (d) outstanding balance amount of the debt being collected, (e) identification information of the relevant contract or source of debt, (f) the terms and condition to paid the outstanding balance, and (g) inform of the available remedies before the Mexican Consumer Protection Agency, among others. (iii) Visits or calls to the domicile of the debtor to collect the due amounts, negotiate or restructure its terms and conditions must abide by the following requirements (i) can only be performed once the payment is due and evidence thereof exists, (ii) those activities must be conducted respectfully, and (iii) those activities will be performed only from Monday to Friday on business days and hours and from 7:00 to 22:00 hours, among others. (iv) The collection activities must be performed only with the debtors, or the joint obligors, as the case may be. (v) Create a document that must be made available and delivered to the client, containing the agreement on the payment and the restructuring conditions. (vi) Once the payment obligation has been fulfilled, a termination letter evidencing such situation issued by the creditor must be delivered to the customer and perform the corresponding actions in the financial information entity to disregard such credit. (vii) Deliver the costumer written evidence of the activities performed to collect the due amounts. Note that judicial enforcement of a Credit under Mexican law is possible. a. Iniquitous and Unconscionable Interest
In case of enforcement of claims in the Philippines, the general principles of equity apply. In applying these principles Philippine courts have discretion to temper interest rates or reduce liquidated damages if shown to be unconscionable or iniquitous. Lenders should not impose iniquitous and unconscionable interest rates (Imperial v. Jaucian, G.R. No. 149004, 14 April 2004). We hasten to add, however, that there is no usury law in the Philippines (please see related answer in #7 below) and the Philippine courts treat claims of this nature with due regard to the attendant circumstances (Bank of the Philippine Islands v. Domingo, G.R. No. 169407, 25 March 2015; Spouses Guevarra v. The Commoner Lending Corp., Inc., G.R. No. 204672, 18 February 2015; Spouses Albos v. Spouses Embisan, G.R. No. 210831, 26 November 2014; Bognot v. RRI Lending Corp., G.R. No. 180144, 24 September 2014).

Law No. 24 of 2009 concerning Flag, Language, Symbol of State and National Anthem (the Language Law) Article 31(1) of the Language Law requires Indonesian language to be used in memoranda of understandings and agreements involving state institutions, government agencies of the Republic of Indonesia, Indonesian private institutions or individual Indonesian citizens. Article 31(1) is not particularly clear as to: (i) whether the term "Indonesian private institutions" includes Indonesian companies or Indonesian branches of foreign companies; or (ii) whether the term "agreements" includes private commercial agreements. The first part of the sentence suggests that the requirement to use Indonesian language relates specifically to diplomatic or public documents and agreements. However, the terms "private institutions" and "agreements" have been interpreted widely, and potentially encompass private or commercial contracts. Further, Article 40 of Language Law states that implementing provisions on use of the Indonesian language will be governed by a Presidential Regulation, which has not been issued up until now. Legally, the Language Law is effective as of the enactment date. However, in the absence of the implementing regulation, it is hard to determine how the Language Law will be applied. Given the uncertainty of the Language Law, parties involved in a transaction have taken the following approaches in both onshore transactions and cross border transactions involving Indonesian parties: a. signing an agreement in both English and Indonesia language at the same time; b. signing an agreement in English only; c. signing an agreement in English and having a version made in Indonesian language (whether or not that version is signed) following the signing of the English version. The first approach is an effort to comply with the Language Law and the second and third approaches are used in an attempt to mitigate an allegation that the parties intentionally violate the Language Law. As "good faith" is an essential element in an Indonesian contract, the expectation is that the court will not nullify the transaction altogether and will be sympathetic to the parties' efforts to provide an Indonesia version at a later stage. Pursuant to the above, it is advisable to prepare an Indonesian version of the loan agreement which will also be signed by the Indonesian borrower. If the timing permits, the preferred approach is to sign the loan agreement in bilingual (English and Indonesian languages) version. The Language Law is silent on whether parties can agree that one language, for example English, is to be used as the prevailing language in an agreement (ie where both the Indonesian and English are executed at the same time). Since there is no prohibition in the Language Law on this approach and based on the freedom of contract principle, the parties should be able to agree that the English version prevails over the Indonesian version. However, please note that it is not certain how an Indonesian court would respond to such a provision should the matter be brought before an Indonesian court. 2. Government Regulation No. 82 of 2012 concerning Electronic System and Transaction Activities (GR 82/2012) GR 82/2012 was issued on 12 October 2012 as an implementing regulation of Law No. 11 of 2008 concerning Electronic Information and Transactions (Law 11/2008). Article 48 of GR 82/2012 rules that electronic contracts and other forms of contract addressed to Indonesian citizens must be made in Indonesian language. GR 82/2012 provides examples of electronic transactions, which are: (i) agreements not made electronically but settled electronically; (ii) agreements made and settled electronically; and (iii) agreements made electronically and not settled electronically. GR 82/2012 does not provide any sanction for violation of Article 48. Further, there is a five-year grace period for compliance with the provisions under GR 82/2012. As a result, the provisions under GR 82/2012 must be complied at the latest five years after the enactment date of GR 82/2012, which will be 12 October 2017. The requirement to use Indonesian language applies to electronic contracts and other forms of contract addressed to Indonesian parties. Therefore, all agreements, contracts, and products addressed to Indonesian parties must be made in Indonesian language, including online click-through contracts. Based on Article 47 (2) of GR 82/2012, an electronic contract is valid if: (i) all parties consent to it; (ii) the parties are capable of making an agreement; (iii) it has a particular object; and (iv) it has a lawful purpose. As long as the online agreement satisfies all the criteria for validity as specified in Article 47 (2), the agreement will be binding on the parties. Given the above, we are of the view that the loan agreement falls within the definition of electronic contract and therefore must be made in Indonesian language. We believe that bilingual version of document should suffice to comply with the requirement under GR 82/2012. Please note that Law 11/2008 shall have jurisdiction over legal acts applicable not only in Indonesia and/or committed by Indonesian citizens, but also applicable to legal acts committed outside jurisdiction of Indonesia by both Indonesian legal entities and foreign legal entities having legal effect in Indonesia. GR 82/2012 is the implementing regulation of Law 11/2008 and has the same jurisdictional scope as Law 11/2008. As such, even though PF is not an Indonesian entity, PF must comply with the use of Indonesian language requirement under GR 82/2012 in extending credit to Indonesian citizens.

IF THE STUDENT WAS OUTSIDE INDIA AT TIME OF EXECUTION OF LOAN AGREEMENT: Ordinarily, extending credit would be subject to the Indian framework applicable to the regulation of banking and financing activities. Under this framework, non-banking entities extending credit are required to register with the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) and fulfill requirements including maintenance of minimum net owned fund value and compliance with a fair practices code. In addition, where the origin of capital inflow is foreign, regulations relating to foreign direct investments may also apply. However, the applicability of this framework is premised on residency of individuals in India as well as the regulated operations being carried out within India.
In this context, we note that PF is a foreign entity with no Indian presence and the proposed model contemplates the primary functions of advancing and disbursing loans occurring outside India. As a result, in our view, the activities as described in the memo would not attract authorisation or licensing requirements ordinarily applicable to the extension of credit.
An additional framework that would ordinarily apply to cross-border lending activities is the Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999 (FEMA). FEMA inter alia regulates the handling of foreign-exchange by individuals and entities resident in India. As a result, Indian students receiving foreign credit would be subject to compliance under FEMA. However, the RBI has clarified that Indian students leaving India to study abroad may be considered ‘non-resident’ under certain circumstances – thereby relaxing compliances required under FEMA (RBI Master Circular on ‘Master Circular on Remittance Facilities for Non-Resident Indians / Persons of Indian Origin / Foreign Nationals’, July 1, 2015, at Para 8.)
In this regard, there is no regulatory clarity on the issue of when a student may begin to be considered a non-resident for the purposes of Indian foreign exchange regulations. In the interest of abundant caution, PF may consider seeking a clarification from the RBI on this issue. At the same time, it may be noted that even if students are considered to be ‘residents’ at the time of the loan agreement, approval or compliance requirements under Indian law, if applicable, would apply only to the borrowing student and not the foreign lender, i.e., PF.
Thus, unless otherwise specified, the Indian regulatory framework described above will not be applicable to the activities described in the memo.

1. CONSUMER PROTECTION ACT, 1986 The Indian framework for consumer protection law is contained in the Consumer Protection Act, 1986 (“CPA”). The CPA provides redress for consumers against defective products, services and misleading advertisements. Under the CPA, consumers may approach quasi-judicial bodies known as consumer fora with complaints. In this regard, PF is required to ensure that all marketing and advertising activities are carried out in a fair, honest and accurate manner.
2. ADVERTISING STANDARDS COUNCIL OF INDIA In addition to the CPA, the Advertising Standards Council of India (“ASCI”) is a self-regulatory body which monitors and enforces standards in advertising. The ASCI has formulated a ‘Code for Self-Regulation in Advertising’ according to which advertisements are required to be ‘true and honest representations’, to be ‘non-offensive’, to not advertise ‘harmful products / situations’, and be ‘fair in competition’. Any person may file complaints with ASCI which will then investigate and issue decisions. Despite being a self-regulatory industry body, decisions of the ASCI are generally complied with by members and many non-members. Therefore, PF is required to ensure that all marketing and advertising activities are carried out in accordance with the ASCI code.

REGULATORY FRAMEWORK: The Indian framework relating to usurious loans by entities other than banks is comprised of the Usurious Loans Act, 1918 (Act) as well as legislations relating to money-lending existing at the level of Indian states. The Act empowers courts in debt-enforcement proceedings to re-open loan transactions where interest rates are ‘excessive’ or where the transaction was ‘substantially unfair’(Section 3(2) of the Usurious Loans Act, 1918). Moreover, the Act empowers courts to exercise discretion in recognizing transactions as loans.
Similarly, state-level legislation addresses issues including excessive interest, reasonable interest rates, repayment and enforcement. However, it may be noted that no uniform legislative approach has been adopted with the effect that the scope, applicability and substance of each legislation may differ substantially.
In relation to the case of PF, it is unclear if Indian laws relating to usury will apply. Banks have been excluded from the purview of both the Act as well as state-level legislation (Section 21A, Banking Regulation Act, 1949). The position with respect to non-banking financial companies (NBFCs; which are regulated by the RBI) remains unclear with various High Courts in India having adopted different positions on the issue. In addition, the purpose of introducing the Act and the various state legislation was clearly to control a certain socio-economic problem of small money lenders lending at unreasonable rates and terms.
However, given that Indian courts may be approached by PF for debt-enforcement and the wide definition accorded to the term ‘loan’ (as per Section 2(2) of the Usurious Loans Act, 1918, “Loan” means a loan whether of money or in kind and includes any transaction which is in the opinion of the Court in substance a loan;), the possibility of the Usurious Loans Act becoming applicable cannot be fully excluded.

The National Credit Act 34 of 2005 ("NCA") governs the extension of credit to consumers in South Africa, and, subject to a few exceptions which are not relevant here, it applies to every credit agreement between parties dealing at arm’s length and made within, or having an effect within the Republic.
In terms of South African law, a contract is made at the place where the offer is accepted. There is therefore a real risk that, if Prodigy Finance makes an offer to a student while that student is in South Africa, and the student accepts the offer in South Africa, the agreement in question would fall within the ambit of the NCA in as much as it would be an "agreement made within South Africa" as contemplated in section 4(1) of the NCA and Prodigy Finance would have to register as a credit provider.

There are no authorization or licensing requirements for the marketing of credit in South Africa. Regulation 21 of the NCA Regulations does however regulate the content of advertisements for credit in South Africa, and Prodigy would have to adhere to the regulations if it were to conduct marketing activities in South Africa.

If a foreign student signs the loan in South Africa, the NCA will apply to the loan agreement if the signature by the student constitutes the acceptance of an offer from Prodigy (and thus the conclusion of the agreement). The position may however be contractually altered by a stipulation that the contract is only made when the student's acceptance reaches Prodigy or when Prodigy signs the agreement in the UK. The NCA also applies to loan agreements which 'have an effect' within South Africa, which is a wide an unqualified criteria which has not yet been judicially considered in the context of the NCA. In light of recent court judgment, it seems likely that the courts will interpret the expression as follows, for purposes of the NCA: • to have an 'effect' within South Africa, the agreement must cause or produce some result or consequence in this country; • that result need not be a negative one, but it must be a direct and substantial result – not a trivial or remote one; and • there must be sufficient jurisdictional links between the credit agreement and its consequences in South Africa. That is, apart from the agreement having some substantial effect within South Africa, the circumstances must be such that a South African court could give an effective or meaningful judgment in relation to the matter.
If the loan funding is disbursed to the student in the UK (into the UK account) and the student (through his instruction to Prodigy) makes payment to a South African University, the only effect which the loan will have in South Africa the payment of the loan funding to the local university. In our view, this link to South Africa is too trivial for purposes of the NCA and the NCA is thus unlikely to apply to such a loan agreement.

Marketing

Servicing (also applicable to Question 8c)

Even though “Marketing” is performed over the internet by using websites, online portals and emails (i.e. without any physical establishment on the territory of Romania), there is a risk that Prodigy Finance’s (“PF”) services may be seen as targeting the Romanian customers and, consequently, PF’s overall activity may be deemed to be oriented to/carried on the Romanian market. Therefore, while the simple public access to the PF’s website (including its Facebook or LinkedIn profiles) should not be construed as falling under the authorisation requirement, the usage of a specific profile criteria search (including university, job title or country of residence) for posting general advertising on social media in order to determine Romanian residents to access such public websites may be considered a “targeting activity” of PF requiring authorisation by the NBR.
In addition, the residence (irrespectively of the place where the agreement has been signed or the fact that the respective customer travels abroad after the connection with the lender has been established) may be seen by the NBR as defining criteria when assessing whether the activity of an entity is oriented to/carried on the territory of Romania (for more details regarding the concept of “place of performance” of the activity, please see the answer to question 2).

In Romania lending is a regulated activity which may be carried out on a professional basis only by credit institutions and financial institutions which are subsidiaries of credit institutions, payment institutions and non-banking financial institutions (“NBFIs”) in accordance with Law No. 93/2009 on non-banking financial institutions (“Law No. 93/2009”).
As regards foreign NBFIs (including those from another EU member states) which intend to provide lending services in Romania, Law No. 93/2009 does not regulate a “passporting” procedure, and therefore, foreign NBFIs could provide services in Romania only if they open a Romanian subsidiary or branch under the NBR’s supervision. We identified legal doctrine stating that NBFIs incorporated in another EU member states could provide direct services in Romania based on the freedom of services imposed by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union; however, following an informal inquiry, NBR’s representatives confirmed us that they do not agree with this opinion and consequently any foreign NBFI (whether or not incorporated in a EU member state) must open a Romanian subsidiary or branch for doing business in Romania. Please note that NBR may issue an official answer in this respect, following a formal inquiry being submitted for this purpose.
In order to operate in Romania, an NBFI/a branch of a foreign NBFI must be registered in the “general registry“ or “special registry” kept by the NBR according to Law No. 93/2009 depending on certain criteria (such as turnover, credits’ volume, assets). The registration is made following the notification regarding the incorporation/opening of the respective NBFI/branch to the NBR within 30 days of their registration with the relevant Romanian Commercial Registry.
The notification requires the submission of a registration request together with certain documents, attesting the fulfilment of legal requirements regarding, among others, minimum value of share capital, reputation and professional experience of the management bodies and integrity of shareholders. In addition, branches of foreign NBFIs must indicate to the NBR the competent authority supervising the activity of the foreign NBFI.
The NBR will approve the registration within 30 days following the complete and correct documentation has been submitted. No lending activity may be done prior to the registration with the NBR (the notification/registration procedure is in fact an “authorisation” by the NBR).
The above requirements apply only in respect of NBFIs intending to provide lending services in Romania. The concept of “in Romania” is not defined as such in current legislation and the existing guidance at EU and national level is inconsistent and refer only to banking services.
Given the lack of any legislation or guidance on this topic, there is a risk that “Lending” services towards Romanian residents (as described in the instructions) may be considered by the NBR as targeting the Romanian market, thus falling under the notification/registration requirements under Law No. 93/2009. Please note that NBR (as the only authority competent to decide whether the activity performed by PF represents lending activity in Romania) may issue an official answer in this respect, following a formal inquiry being submitted for this purpose.

Although there is no specific Romanian legal provision or guidance as regards “Servicing” (as described in the instructions), there is a risk that, given the ancillary nature of such activities, NBR considers “Servicing” an integral part of lending activity, which is subject to authorisation by the NBR (for more details, please see the response to question 2).

Theoretically, the offer of credit should not be extended to the student whilst he or she is in Trinidad and Tobago as Prodigy Finance would be deemed to be doing banking business or business of a financial nature in Trinidad and Tobago in breach of the FIA. The offer of credit should be extended and all other activity should be performed outside of Trinidad and Tobago when the student is outside of Trinidad and Tobago to avoid triggering any licensing requirements. However, as in 1. above this is another grey area. We mention here that there are practical exceptions to the general prohibition against foreign companies or institutions granting loans to individuals and corporations resident in Trinidad and Tobago. In the past one-off lending transactions by foreign banks have not met with any objections from local banks or the Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago. Although the offering of the loan by Prodigy is a lending activity, it may be one of those areas where the Central Bank may not intervene, because the loan would be granted in the United Kingdom and the student would have protection of the courts in the United Kingdom. Note, frequency would also be an issue with respect to the offering of the loans. If the activity is, however, deemed to be frequent, a foreign company will be required to register a branch office or external company for the purpose of continuing with such business. There is, however, no definition of what would be deemed to be regular business or set precedent to guide practitioners. From our review of the background information, it appears that Prodigy’s business is not a one-off transaction as Prodigy would be extending loans on a continuous basis. In the circumstances, Prodigy may be required to be licensed under the FIA.

We are aware that several years ago loans were extended to Trinidad and Tobago students in a foreign jurisdiction. Some students defaulted on payment of these loans and enforcement claims were brought in the courts of Trinidad and Tobago without the intervention of the Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago. However, we wish to advise that if Prodigy Finance carries out (through agents) enforcement actions in Trinidad and Tobago and continuously sends statements, arrears notices, collections and updates by courier to students resident in Trinidad and Tobago, it may run the risk of the Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago becoming aware of same and as such, the Central Bank may inquire into Prodigy’s affairs in Trinidad and Tobago.
The FIA states that if the Central Bank has reasonable grounds to believe that a person is carrying on any aspect of the business of a financial nature without a licence issued under the FIA, it may require information from, inquire into and examine the affairs of that person and may take action that the Central Bank sees fit to ensure that the person discontinues the activity in question, including, without limitation, the issue of a compliance direction. If Prodigy is deemed to be doing business of a financial nature and requires a licence, the FIA states that where a person carries on business of a financial nature without a licence issued or deemed to be issued under the said Act, the person commits an offence. Where the person is a company, every officer and director of such company is liable to a fine of five million dollars and to imprisonment for five years and in the case of a continuing offence, to a fine of five hundred thousand dollars for each day that the offence continues. In addition, the company is also liable on summary conviction to a fine of five million dollars and in the case of a continuing offence, to a fine of five hundred thousand dollars for each day that the offence continues. See explanatory note at 1 on how to comply.

The Extension of Credit, including executing the loan agreement, is considered as a commercial activity for Prodigy Finance (Art. 6 Syrian Trade Law of 2007). If the student was within the Syrian jurisdiction at the time he executed the loan agreement, this would mean that Prodigy Finance has begun performing its commercial activity of Extension of Credit in Syria. Foreign legal persons, including companies, are prohibited from exercising any commercial activity in Syria unless they are registered at the Ministry of Economy and Internal Trade (the Ministry) and obtained the necessary permits (Art. 3(1) Law 34 of 2008). Consequently, Prodigy Finance would then need to register a branch office with the Ministry in Syria according to Law 34 of 2008. Accordingly, the branch office must be entered in a special commercial register and recorded with the Department for Foreign Companies at the Ministry. The formal application for registration must be accompanied by a number of documents including Prodigy Finance’s Articles of Association and an extract from its entry at the commercial register in its home country, as well as resolutions drafted by its management concerning the establishment of the branch office and the appointment of a managing director of the branch. In addition, a power of attorney which authorizes the managing director to represent the company in all administrative, financial, and technical matters, as well as the most recent annual accounts of Prodigy Finance must be submitted to the Ministry. All these documents must be legalized up to the Syrian embassy in the country of issue, and in Syria they would need to be translated into Arabic, and approved by the Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Interior. The time framework of obtaining these approvals for the documents is about five months. If the appointed manager of the branch was a foreigner, he would have to obtain a work permit from the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs. In addition, considering that the Extension of Credit activity is considered as a banking activity (Art. 12 Law 28 of 2001 and Art. 85(2) Law 23 of 2001), registering the Prodigy Finance’s branch would require obtaining a license from the Central Bank (Art. 90 Law 23 of 2001 and Art. 18 Law 28 of 2001). The time frame for opening the branch office and having it operative in Syria is about eight months (including the five months needed for having approval on the documents in Syria). Violating the above provision, i.e., signing loan agreements with students residing in Syria without registering a branch office in Syria is punishable by suspending its activity in Syria. Therefore, it is recommended that Prodigy Finance should not have any Syrian student execute a loan agreement while he is in Syria.

• Prodigy Finance can agree with a student in the loan agreement upon the rate of interest on the loan amount and on the rate of interest to be applied in the event of delay in effecting payment, or in any other case in which interest has been stipulated, provided that this rate of interest does not exceed nine per cent. If the parties agree to a rate exceeding nine per cent, the court would have to reduce the interest rate to nine per cent and any surplus that has been paid must be refunded. Any commission or other consideration to whatsoever nature stipulated by Prodigy Finance which, together with the agreed interest, exceeds the maximum limits of interest of nine per cent, will be considered as disguised interest and would be subject to reduction, if it is not established that this commission or this consideration is in respect of a service actually rendered by Prodigy Finance or of a lawful consideration (Art. 228 Syrian Civil Code). In this relation, it has to be noted that the choice of English law and arbitration clause contained in the agreement loan are valid and enforceable under Syrian law. However, a clause in an arbitration award issued in relation to the loan agreement which violates the Syrian public order might not be enforced in Syria. Accordingly, a clause in an arbitration award issued in relation to the loan agreement which imposes interest rate on the student exceeding nine per cent would be enforced in Syria only up to the limit of nine per cent.
• In case the student was in Syria when he signs the loan agreement, the mandatory provisions in the Syrian Consumer Protection Law No. 14 of 2015 (Law 14 of 2015) would apply to the activities of the transaction that takes place in Syria. Accordingly, providing the pre-contract information by Prodigy Finance must be in Arabic language with the possibility of using another language with it (Art. 53 Law 14 of 2015). In addition, such information, or any marketing activity of the loans, should be correct and not misleading (Art. 54 Law 14 of 2015). The contract itself must not be in Arabic. Violating any of these two requirements is punishable by imprisonment up to two months and/or a fine up to fifty thousand Syrian Pounds (Art. 33 Law 14 of 2015). Accordingly, if Prodigy Finance intends to have the students execute the loan agreement while they are in Syria, it would have to prepare the pre contract information in Arabic.
• Transfer of money, whether in foreign or Syrian currency, outside Syria is prohibited (except in a few exceptional cases that do not include the transfer for the repayment of a loan agreement used outside Syria) and it is punishable by hard labour of up to 5 years (Art. 21 Syrian Economic Criminal Law No. 3 of 2013). Accordingly, if Prodigy Finance makes any demand of payment against a student who is residing in Syria (e.g., for the repayment of the loan), he can argue that he is prohibited by the Syrian law from transferring the payments abroad to repay. Further, in case Prodigy Finance would like to enforce any arbitration award against a student inside Syria which entails the payment of certain amounts as a repayment of the loan or for any other related reason, Prodigy Finance would not be able to transfer this money outside Syria.

Consumer Protection: The National Bank of Georgia has adopted regulations that must be observed by commercial banks in Georgia while providing information to the consumers about banking services. The commercial banks are required to ensure that the consumers are provided with accurate, clear, complete, necessary and timely information on banking services. The regulations also stipulate minimum information that must be included in the credit agreements, such as, (i) duration of credit; (ii) total amount of the credit; (iii) interest rate; (iv) possible amount of the penalty and method of its calculation; etc. As per the business model, PF is neither licensed as a bank nor as a credit institution. Furthermore, the regulations described above only apply to commercial banks and branch offices of foreign banks operating in Georgia. Irrespective of this, we still decided to bring this to your attention, since these consumer protection regulations relate to the business model of PF.
Data Protection: Georgia has recently adopted regulations in the field of personal data protection that may be relevant for PF in the process of carrying out the business model. The Law on Personal Data Protection dated December 28, 2011, regulates processing and protection of personal data of natural persons. The Law includes, inter alia, the requirement to obtain the consent of a natural person in respect of processing of his personal data, as well as certain data protection requirements to ensure protection of such information from unauthorized access and disclosure. Notably, transfer of personal data abroad (across the Georgian border) may be subject to regulatory consent in cases specified by laws of Georgia. Namely, such consent may be required unless data is transferred to the countries with adequate personal data protection guarantees in place. Extension of Credit by Prodigy Finance to students who are residents of Ukraine would not constitute lending which would require Prodigy Finance to be licensed in Ukraine.
However, under Ukrainian law, a loan agreement between non-resident lender and Ukrainian resident borrower is subject to a mandatory registration with the National Bank of Ukraine (the “NBU”). Such registration must be carried out by the borrower through its local servicing bank.
For the purposes of Ukrainian currency control regulations, a person would be deemed a “resident” of Ukraine if such person (i) lives at least one year on the territory of Ukraine, (ii) does not have a permanent place of residence elsewhere abroad and (iii) intends to live in Ukraine for an unlimited period of time without limiting such living to any specific purpose. Based strict application of these criteria, a move abroad for a period of time to study should not affect the residency status of a student who qualified as a “resident” at the time of entry into the loan agreement.
The registration with the NBU must be done prior to actual disbursement of a loan under the loan agreement. The applicable NBU regulations would not permit a disbursement of the loan to a Ukrainian individual, unless such disbursement is made to such individual’s:
(i) local account; (ii) account opened abroad and for which an individual licence of the NBU is obtained; or (iii) account opened abroad and used during such individual’s stay outside of Ukraine (which would be exempted from the NBU individual licencing requirement).
Accordingly, to the extent the Extension of Credit contemplates disbursement of the loan directly to the university account or some general client account opened with Prodigy Finance not in the name of the respective Ukrainian individual, the NBU may refuse to register the loan agreement.
As a practical matter, it is possible to approach the NBU with request to provide a clarification on certain matters within the scope of NBU’s regulation (e.g., on the matter of interpretation of unclear provisions in an NBU’s regulation). At the same time, the NBU would most likely be reluctant to give a definitive answer as to whether it would register or not a particular loan agreement (without reviewing relevant documentation and given that there is no procedure for such pre-clearance/pre-review). In addition, such clarification letters from NBU are not legally binding and there would be no guarantee that the NBU would adhere to the same position during the registration of a particular loan agreement.

NBU Regulation No. 270 "On the Procedure for Obtaining Foreign Currency Loans by Residents and Extending Foreign Currency Loans by Residents to Non-Residents", NBU Regulation No. 363 "On Establishment of the Maximum Interest Rates under External Borrowings of the Residents":
Ukrainian borrowers can make payments under cross-border loan agreements to foreign lenders only in accordance with the terms of registration of such loan agreements with the NBU. The aggregate amount of all payments under loan agreement for the use of a loan (including interest payments, fees, charges, penalties and other similar amounts) must not exceed the amount of payments calculated based on the applicable maximum interest rate set by the NBU. The maximum interest rates currently set by the NBU are as follows:
• for fixed interest rate loans with a maturity of up to 1 year – 9.8% p.a., for loans with a maturity of 1 to 3 years – 10% p.a. and for loans with a maturity of over 3 years – 11% p.a.; and • for floating interest rate loans – 3m Libor+750bps. The loan agreement must contain a specific wording on the maximum interest rate limitation. In addition, the loan agreement must also provide that it becomes effective upon (or not earlier than) its registration with the NBU.
The Law of Ukraine "On Protection of Consumers' Rights":
Ukrainian consumer laws provide for a concept of “consumer loan”. Due to ambiguity in the law, there is a risk that a loan extended by foreign lender to Ukrainian individual may in theory be viewed as “consumer loan”. In such case, a loan agreement must comply with a number of requirements under the Ukrainian consumer laws. As example, the loan agreement must allow early repayment by the borrower and must not allow assignment of lender’s rights without borrower’s consent or contain any provisions that qualify as “unfair” conditions under the consumer laws. Further, a borrower under the consumer loan would enjoy certain additional statutory protections (such as an unconditional right to opt out of the loan within 14 days from its execution). At the same time, we believe this risk is theoretical and it can be argued that the Ukrainian consumer laws should not apply to the loans provided by Prodigy Finance to Ukrainian individuals pursuant to the Extension of Credit.
Separately, while the Servicing contemplates sending notices and other communications through electronic means, please note that there is a risk that electronic notices/communications may not be admissible in evidence for the purposes of the Ukrainian court proceedings.

The usury is forbidden under both the civil and criminal law.
Under the usurious contract, one party takes advantage of the other party’s emergency, difficult material position, its lack of experience, frivolity or dependence (subjective condition) and assures to himself or to someone else a benefit that is in obvious disproportion to his own obligation (objective condition). The other party can request the appropriate reduction of the interest rate from the court; otherwise, the contract would be declared null and void.
In criminal law, usury means the taking or assuring of a disproportionate benefit in the return for granting a loan (objective condition), whereby the lender is taking advantage of the borrower’s difficult material position, difficult circumstances, need, lack of cognitive abilities or frivolity (subjective condition). The penalty is imprisonment up to three years and a fine.
The courts decide on a case-by-case basis whether the specific loan is in violation of the cited usury regulations, for which both subjective and objective condition must be met.

Law on Consumer Credit of the Republic of Lithuania (Consumer Credit Law) governs consumer credit services in Lithuania. As a general rule, under the Consumer Credit Law, a legal entity may engage into consumer credit business in Lithuania only once the supervisory authority enlists the legal entity into the public list of consumer credit providers. However, the Consumer Credit Law does not provide further explanation as to what exactly constitutes provision of consumer credit services in the territory of Lithuania. There is no authoritative guidance in Lithuania in this respect as well.
For the purpose of determining whether the consumer credit services are provided within or outside the territory of Lithuania, the Commission Interpretative Communication – Freedom to provide services and the interest of the general good in the Second Banking Directive (SEC(97) 1193 final) (the “Communication”) should be taken into account. The Communication is formally not applicable as it draws the line in the situations where the banks licensed in one EU member state are acting in the territory of the other EU member state. However, in our view, the Communication might be applied to consumer credit activities following the principle of analogy.
In particular, the following conditions shall be considered while determining whether the consumer credit services are provided outside of the territory of Lithuania:
(i) the Lithuanian client must have initiated the contact with the consumer credit provider (not vice-a-versa), and must enter into an agreement for services with that consumer credit provider outside Lithuania, and (ii) services are rendered outside the territory of Lithuania and provided within the framework of the agreement entered into, and (iii) the consumer credit provider does not conduct any general advertising or marketing of its services within the territory of Lithuania with intention to provide services in Lithuania (or) its marketing and advertising is not directed to persons residing in Lithuania; (iv) the counterparty is the occasional Lithuanian client of consumer credit provider.
The criteria listed in (i) to (iii) are cumulative and they should be complied with as far as possible. Regarding criteria (iv) there is no sufficient legal guidance to determine what number of Lithuanian clients increases the risk of interpretation that consumer credit services are provided in Lithuania.
Based on the criteria indicated above, a principle of reverse solicitation (i.e. client initiating the contact) should be considered applicable to provision of consumer credit services outside Lithuania. If Lithuanian clients approach consumer credit provider located outside Lithuania and request consumer credit services, such approach may be regarded as reverse solicitation and should not trigger regulatory (and licensing) requirements, provided that such services are rendered outside the territory of Lithuania.
Nevertheless, in case the services were provided due to the client initiating the contact, a question as to whether services fall within the category of reverse solicitation is subject to the nature of the services, the actions of the consumer credit provider and the client. The provision of services, by way of reverse solicitation, must be carried out exclusively on the basis of the client’s unsolicited approach and no promotion may be performed by the consumer credit provider within a territory of Lithuania. In our professional understanding, marketing information provided in the memo should be in line with principle of reverse solicitation and should not trigger regulatory (licensing) requirements.
Please note that if students complete pre-contractual formalities while they are in Lithuania the risk increases that reverse solicitation principle may be breached. If PF employees are visiting Lithuania, PF will most likely not be able to rely on the reverse solicitation principle. In such case there is a risk for the service to be treated as provided in the territory of Lithuania and it might be considered as the “characteristic performance” (as described in the Communication).

The Credit Institutions Act provides that if lending activity (“providing/granting loans”) is performed within the territory of Bulgaria (by a bank/credit institution, when lending amounts accumulated from publicly attracted deposits, or by a financial institution, when providing loans as business, which represents essential part of the provider’s overall activity, without publicly attracting deposits) such activity requires licensing or registration by the Bulgarian National Bank (“BNB”).
The law does not define in which cases lending activity is considered to be performed within the territory of Bulgaria. We are also not aware of any interpretation expressed by the BNB or any court decisions on the matter. The question as to when lending on a cross border basis is deemed to be banking activity within the territory of Bulgaria is open to interpretation. Also, the law does not define if “providing/granting loans” includes also marketing or just extension of loans. In this questionnaire we express our own interpretation and views on these questions. However, we ought to underline that these views and interpretation are not currently clear in Bulgarian law or practice. i) Residence of the client: Subject to the above general note, in our view the mere fact that a client is a Bulgaria-resident student when “Marketing” commences or for “Services”, as set out in the instructions to us, is not sufficient to determine that such lending is provided within the territory of Bulgaria. ii) Place of extension: Further, we understand that Prodigy Finance shall disburse the funds from a UK bank account directly to a UK account of the client, i.e. even if the place of granting or receiving the loan might be considered as a sufficient trigger to determine whether the lending services are carried out on the territory of Bulgaria, the lending performed by Prodigy Finance should not be considered as such. iii) Solicitation: In our view the solicitation is probably the most logical trigger for determining when lending activity is performed within the territory of Bulgaria, because by actively soliciting (i.e. seeking) clients in Bulgaria a potential lending services provider virtually establishes itself on the local market and becomes indirectly a participant on it. However, we understand Prodigy Finance will not pro-actively target Bulgaria-resident students, but the students will approach Prodigy Finance. In such case, in our view, it would be an extreme conclusion to state that Bulgarian law would prohibit Prodigy Finance to provide those services to a Bulgarian client.
Therefore, it seems to us that as (a) Prodigy Finance is not actively soliciting clients on the Bulgarian market, but on reverse enquiry basis, (b) the loan agreements will be executed once the students are in the jurisdiction of their school. i.e. outside Bulgaria, and (c) the loans shall be disbursed from a UK account to another UK account, it could be argued that Project Finance does not carry out lending activity within the territory of Bulgaria and is not subject to the licensing/registration requirements.
However, absent any guidance issued by the local regulator about (a) what “unsolicited” marketing would be and (b) what the criteria to differentiate between “cross-border activity” and “activity within Bulgaria” are, leads to uncertainty as to the regulatory interpretation which the regulator may adopt, therefore executing the loan agreement when the student is in Bulgaria, might be used as an argument that the lending activity is performed within Bulgaria, though we do not support such view.
