Several matters must be taken account regarding this question. As a rule, the rendering of financial services by a foreign company in Colombia requires the incorporation of a Rep Office in order to promote business from abroad.
Pursuant to Part 4 of Decree 2555 of 2010, any act of promotion involving foreign financial products and/or services (e.g. loans) in Colombia or to Colombian residents by a “Foreign Institution” (defined as a any entity incorporated outside of Colombia, including agencies of Foreign Institutions established in Colombia, whose purpose and activity is the offering of financial products and/or services, and are supervised and regulated by the laws of their domicile of incorporation) can only be done through a representative office ("Rep Office"), previously and duly authorized by the Colombian Superintendence of Finance (the "SFC"). Please note that under the relevant regulations, "Promotion" means any communication or message, made personally or by any other means, whether or not on a mass scale, with the purpose or effect of initiating, directly or indirectly, the purchase of a product or the rendering of a service of the financial or securities market. Consequently, almost every act may be deemed as Promotion and the line between research activities and marketing activities may be very thin. In order to establish a Rep Office, Prodigy Finance would require filing a formal application to the SFC accompanied with the documentations set forth in Part 4 of Decree 2555 of 2010.
The different documents and requirements for the application are intended to prove the regulatory and surveillance status of Prodigy Finance, its legal authorization to render those products and/or services in its country of domicile and to establish a Representative Office or enter into a Referral Agreement in Colombia, its financial stability and compliance with AML standards, and the features and quality of the products and/or services that it is intending to offer, among others. The SFC has the authority to request further information, according to applicable regulations. Please note that Rep Offices may only act as marketing vehicles, and are not authorized to execute any agreement involving the services that they promote. Rep Offices may only act as referral agents, as a channel of communication between Prodigy Finance and its clients in Colombia. One of the main exceptions to the Rep Office requirement is the "Reverse Solicitation", which occurs when a potential investor demands information from Prodigy Finance and no marketing efforts caused such initial interest (i.e. without any prior Promotion activity by Prodigy Finance). Please note that Colombian laws and regulations do not make a distinction between existing clients and new clients; therefore, in the event of Reverse Solicitation, any activities following the initial contact are done within such exception, and therefore their execution will be allowed by Colombian regulation as long as the information provided to the client (existing or new) exclusively relies upon the specific product and/or service. Bearing in mind the foregoing, these marketing activities, whether paid or unpaid, could be deemed as Promotion; therefore, Prodigy Finance would only be allowed to carry them out with the due participation of the Rep Office. Please note that this does not mean that the Rep Office must directly carry out the marketing activities, but it is at least required that the Rep Offices staff (applicable regulations require that Rep Offices at least have a legal representative) is aware of all Promotion activities carried out in Colombia or directed to Colombian residents.
According to the information provided, we know that that Prodigy Finance has both a regulated and a non-regulated business. Instead, for the promotion of financial services provided by non-regulated entities, there are no applicable rules which specifically regulate this matter. So whenever providing loans Colombia the general rules applicable for the allocation of credit results will be applicable to Prodigy Finance, but such credit allocation will also be limited by the general restrictions for the Promotion of cross-border loans and its marketing

Given that Polish law does not state an explicit legal criteria that could be used to determine that, this is mostly a factual matter which should be analysed on a case-by-case basis. In this sense, following a review of the introductory memorandum, in our view there are reasonable arguments to support the thesis that Prodigy Finance should be not be found to be conducting business activity in Poland. There are two main arguments to support this view. Firstly, Prodigy Finance does not directly market its lending products specifically to the Polish market or to Polish customers. Secondly, it is a Polish customer who initiates contact with Prodigy Finance as the provider of an actual loan, whereas the mere fact of that customer’s potential residence in Poland and execution of the loan agreement in Poland should not, in our view, be of a decisive nature in supporting the opposite thesis. Given the above, the applicability of Polish law to Prodigy Finance’s business activity will be limited to mandatory overriding provisions of law resulting mostly from the fact that Prodigy Finance deals with Polish consumers.
The extent to which the provisions of Polish law may have an overriding nature is set out in Regulation (EC) No. 593/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 June 2008 on the law applicable to contractual obligations (Rome I). Pursuant to Art. 6.2 of Rome I, the parties may choose which law will govern a contract, however such choice may not deprive the consumer of the protection afforded to him/her by provisions that cannot be derogated from by agreement by virtue of the law which, in the absence of choice, would have applied on the basis of Rome I. As such, the Polish legal acts listed below (which in fact implement EU directives) include overriding consumer rules which may apply to the relationship between Prodigy Finance e and a Polish student.
1) The Civil Code dated 23 April 1964 as amended (the Civil Code) states a maximum interest rate related to legal actions. If the rate is exceeded, then the maximum interest rate will apply and must be paid. The Civil Code also contains general rules and principles such as the definition of a consumer and the manner of executing and concluding contracts. The Civil Code provides a non-exhaustive list of potentially abusive (unfair) clauses which, when introduced to an individual contract with a consumer, are not binding on the consumer.
2) The Act on Consumer Credit dated 12 May 2011, as amended, which, among others, implements Directive 2008/48/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 April 2008 on credit agreements for consumers and repeals Council Directive 87/102/EEC.
3) The Act on Consumer Rights dated 30 May 2014 as amended, which, among others, implements Directive 2011/83/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2011 on consumer rights, amends Council Directive 93/13/EEC and Directive 1999/44/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, and repeals Council Directive 85/577/EEC and Directive 97/7/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council.
4) The Act on Competition and Consumer Protection dated 16 February 2007 as amended, which, among others, implements Directive 98/27/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 19 May 1998 on injunctions for the protection of consumers' interests.
5) The Act on Combating Unfair Commercial Practices dated 23 August 2007, as amended, which, among others, implements Directive 2005/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the council of 11 May 2005 concerning unfair business-to-consumer commercial practices in the internal market and amends Council Directive 84/450/EEC, Directives 97/7/EC, 98/27/EC and 2002/65/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and Regulation (EC) No. 2006/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council.
6) The Act on Combating Unfair Competition dated 16 April 1993, as amended.
7) The Act on Electronically Supplied Services dated 18 July 2002, as amended, which, among others, implemented Directive 2000/31/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 8 June 2000 on certain legal aspects of information society services, in particular electronic commerce, in the Internal Market.
Regarding the legal acts listed above, the Polish Competition and Consumer Protection Office (the CCPO) can conduct proceedings in the case of practices which infringe collective consumer interests. The CCPO may force entrepreneurs to cease the challenged actions and to remove the on-going effects of the infringement, as well as impose fines. The CCPO may also issue an interim decision (before the end of the proceedings in the case of practices which infringe collective consumer interests) which obliges entrepreneurs to discontinue certain activities to prevent serious and potentially irreversible threats to consumers. The CCPO can also conduct proceedings which will lead to some contract provisions being declared illegal. In such case, these provisions will cease to be binding.
In addition to the above, each consumer may also bring an action to an ordinary court to defend his/her rights under the above regulations. In such case, the court may decide that a particular provision in a contract is not binding on parties to it or a particular legal action taken under such provision might be considered as ineffective.

The parties to a Polish law-governed agreement are allowed to agree an interest rate, including both interest for using the capital and penalty/default interest on unpaid sums, insofar as this is not contradictory to the provisions of Civil Law on the maximum permissible interest rate.
Statutory interest rates are regulated by the Civil Code. We distinguish: (i) statutory interest on a pecuniary sum (interest for using the capital) (the Interest on Capital); and (ii) statutory interest for a delay (a penalty for not making a payment on time) (the Penalty Interest).
The calculation method is similar for both rates and is based on the reference rate of the National Bank of Poland (the Reference Rate). The Reference Rate is published on the National Bank of Poland’s official website (http://www.nbp.pl/) and is 150 bps as on the date of this questionnaire.
The Interest on Capital is calculated as the sum of the Reference Rate and 350 bps. As of the date of this questionnaire, this is 5 per cent. per annum.
The Penalty Interest is calculated as the sum of the Reference Rate and 550 bps. As of the date of this questionnaire, it is 7 per cent. per annum.
The parties may agree different rates (e.g. EURIBOR) if they do not exceed the maximum statutory rate, which is twice the Interest on Capital or the Penalty Interest respectively. As of the date of this questionnaire, the maximum Interest on Capital is 10 per cent. per annum and the maximum Penalty Interest is 14 per cent. per annum.
Usury is a criminal offence in Poland pursuant to Art. 304 of Criminal Code dated 6 June 1997 as further amended.

Where Article 5 or Article 7 of the Rome Convention apply, the following mandatory requirements under the Danish Credit Agreement Act and the Danish Consumer Contracts Act applies:
Under the Danish Credit Agreement Act, PF must inter alia; • Provide specific pre-contractual information on paper or other durable medium which enables the student to compare the offer of credit with other offers, in order to make an informed decisions of the execution of the loan agreement. This information includes, inter alia, the type of credit, the credit term and the interest rate. The information may be provided using the Standard European Consumer Credit Information form. • Assess the creditworthiness of the student before execution of the loan agreement. • Drawn up the loan agreement on paper or another durable medium and clearly state in the agreement, inter alia, the type of credit, credit amount, Annual Percentage Rate, and possibilities to terminate or withdraw from the loan agreement as well as other required information.
The students have a right to cancel under the Danish Credit Agreements Act. A student must inform PF of the cancellation within 14 days from the day where the loan agreement was concluded or the day where the student received the terms of the loan and the required information.
As the loans are executed as distance contracts, the Danish Consumer Contracts Act required that; • PF in a clear and comprehensible manner gives the students certain information before the loan agreement is concluded. The information requirement is to a large extent equivalent to the information requirement under the Danish Credit Agreement Act, but also includes e.g. information on any choice of law or arbitration clauses in the contract. • PF gives the students a confirmation of the loan agreement on a durable medium within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the contract and at the latest at the time of disbursement of the credit.
The rules under the Danish Credit Agreement Act and Danish Consumer Contra cannot be contracted out of to the detriment of the students. This means, that the Danish Credit Agreement Act applies to the extent that the students are not provided better protection under English law, since the parties are to make an express choice of English law to govern the loan agreement.
PF is not subject to the Danish Marketing Practice Act, provided that all marketing and sale of the loans are only performed on an online basis. • Notwithstanding this, the Danish Marketing Practice Act applies with respect to unsolicited marketing. Therefore, PF must not approach anyone by means of electronic mail, an automated call-ing system or facsimile machine to market their loans unless the student concerned has requested him to do so. • Provided that all marketing and sale of the loans is not only performed on an online basis the Danish Marketing Practice Act will apply. Consequently, PF must exercise good marketing practice. Further, PF must, inter alia, give appropriate guidance in accordance with the nature of the loan to the student when the loan agreement is executed, as this is of importance for the assess-ment of the loan and PF must provide the consumer with all relevant information of importance to the consumer's decision to enter into the loan agreement. • Furthermore, with regard to advertising of credit agreements, which indicates an interest rate or any figures relating to the cost of the credit to the consumer, PF is required to provide information to the consumer, which shall be specified in a clear, concise and prominent way by means of a representative example. Such information must be made available in connection with the promotion of the loan. The information requirement is to a large extent equivalent to the infor-mation requirement under the Danish Credit Agreement Act.

The Danish Criminal Code and the Danish Credit Agreements Act prohibit usury.
Whether an interest rate level (and Annual Percentage Rate level) on consumer finance loans risk being deemed usury (criminal law) or contrary to the general clause of the Danish Credit Agreements Act or Danish Contracts Act (civil law) will be subject to a case by case analysis of whether the interest rate and costs are unreasonable and whether the lender could be considered to have taken advantage of the customer's considerable financial or personal difficulties, lack of insight or irresponsibility.
There is no set interest rate level which is directly deemed as usury. Generally, the fact that a loan is unsecured renders a higher interest rate level more acceptable. Additionally, the higher credit risk the creditor has, the higher interest level will be accepted.
From a civil law perspective, although no cap on interest rate levels apply, case precedent from the Danish Complaint Board of Banking Services (in Danish "Pengeinstitutankenævnet") may have a stronger tendency to find interest rates/costs or default rates unreasonable under the Danish Credit Agreement Act than the courts.
Should any interest rate and/or costs (including the default interest rate) be deemed contrary to the general clause of the Danish Credit Agreement Act and/or the Danish Contracts Act the interest rate/costs will be retroactively decreased.

It follows from the Law of the Kyrgyz Republic on Transactions in Foreign Currency that Kyrgyz residents shall register their accounts and deposits opened/made abroad with the National Bank of the Kyrgyz Republic. Thus, a student having received a loan shall register its account opened abroad with the National Bank of the Kyrgyz Republic and also provide information on such an account to the National Bank. It is necessary to file a notification of the approved format specifying details of a Kyrgyz resident opening an account or making a deposit, details of a foreign bank where the account is opened or the deposit is made along with the detailed information on the opened account/deposit made. The notification shall be mailed (via registered mail) or delivered by courier. Kyrgyz residents having accounts/deposits at foreign banks shall provide a report of the established format on the balance of funds remaining on the account/deposit as of the end of the previous quarter (separately for each account/deposit) quarterly before the 15th day of the month following the reporting quarter. The report shall be mailed (via registered mail) or delivered by courier to the National Bank’s forwarding department.

Under the Civil Code, rights of the borrower to terminate a loan agreement cannot be limited or worsened under the loan agreement concluded between the parties.
Furthermore, under the Regulation on "Lending rules for banks" adopted by the Central Bank of Azerbaijan, a loan agreement must contain the following provisions in order to meet the formal requirements: (i) purpose of a loan; (ii) conditions of a loan (amount and term of a loan; annual interest rate; commission fees (if any); other payments required by the lender); (iii) repayment schedule; (iv) grace period and repayment conditions; (v) procedures for amendments and additions to the loan agreement; (vi) rights and obligations of the parties; (vii) dispute resolution. A lender shall inform the borrower about the above conditions in a detailed form prior to execution of a loan agreement and a relevant note must be made on the loan agreement in this regard.
It should also be noted that under the Constitution of the Republic of Azerbaijan every person may apply to the appropriate court as stipulated by law. A case to which a person is a party cannot be heard in another court without the consent of that person. It may be inferred from the above provision that any person may choose the appropriate court jurisdiction. Moreover, the Civil Procedure Code of Azerbaijan provides that every person may defend his/her rights in court and waiver of that right is considered ineffective and invalid. This provision may be interpreted by local courts as applicable only to Azerbaijani courts and that consequently any agreement not to commence an action or excluding application to the local courts should be considered ineffective. In our view, however, this would be a literalist approach and would distort the very principle of this provision, the protection of rights by legal remedies, including the right to commence an action in the jurisdiction chosen by a person.

Regulated activities only fall within the scope of the licence requirements under the Financial Supervision Act (Wet op het financieel toezicht, FSA) if they are carried out in the Netherlands. However, the FSA does not state when a regulated activity is carried out in the Netherlands. The Dutch Authority for the Financial Markets (Autoriteit Financiële Markten, AFM) has adopted the view, following MiFID, that the services and activities of an investment firms occur ‘in the Netherlands’ if they are offered to clients who are located in the Netherlands. This would mean that the marketing of credit, the extension of a credit agreement and the servicing of such an agreement would be regulated in the Netherlands if these activities are offered to Dutch residents. To limit this scope, the AFM takes the view that regulated activities do not take place in the Netherlands and therefore is permitted provided that the initiative test's requirements are met: (i) The Dutch prospects/clients contacted PF at their own initiative; (ii) PF has neither marketed PF nor promoted its services in the Dutch market (by personal visits, advertising, websites, e-mails or otherwise); and (iii) PF does neither offer additional services to the Dutch prospects/clients nor actively seeks to expand any mandate received from them, i.e. if the original relationship was established in compliance with the initiative test, PF may actively solicit products and services as long as they fall under the same category as the initially agreed products and services.
Since PF will market extending loans in the Netherlands on its own initiative, the requirements for the initiative test are not met. Therefore, this activity is regulated and requires a license from the AFM.
